action.action-desc: Mr. Marchant introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Ways and Means

form.official-title: To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to provide for International Regulated Investment Companies.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the International Regulated Investment Company Act of 2017.

subsection.text: Subchapter N of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by redesignating part V as part VI and inserting after part IV the following new part:

toc.toc-entry: Sec. 998. Definition of international regulated investment company.

section.header: Definition of International regulated investment company

subsection.text: For purposes of this title, the terms international regulated investment company and IRIC mean, with respect to any taxable year, a domestic corporation which, at all times during the taxable year, meets the following requirements:

paragraph.text: The corporation is registered under the Investment Company Act of 1940.
Except as provided in subsection (c), the corporation holds no assets other than the stock of a single regulated investment company—

subparagraph.text: to which part I of subchapter M applies, and
which is not a qualified investment entity (as defined in section 897(h)(4)(A)(ii)).

paragraph.text: All outstanding stock of the corporation is held by nonresident alien individuals (and their foreign estates) and qualified foreign pension funds (within the meaning of section 897(l)(2)).
The corporation has in effect an election to be treated as an IRIC.

subsection.text: An election to be treated as an IRIC shall apply to the taxable year for which made and all subsequent taxable years until terminated. Such election shall be made for any taxable year not later than the due date (with extensions) for the return of tax imposed by this subtitle for the taxable year.
For purposes of subsection (a)(2), an IRIC may hold—

paragraph.text: an amount of cash and cash equivalents reasonably necessary or appropriate for the corporation to conduct its normal affairs, and
such other assets as are incidental to the corporation’s conduct of its normal affairs or otherwise allowed by the Secretary.

Except as provided in paragraph (2), if a corporation fails to meet the requirements of subsection (a) at any time during the taxable year, the corporation shall not be treated as an IRIC for such taxable year.

subparagraph.text: A corporation which fails to meet the requirements of subsection (a) for any taxable year shall nevertheless be considered to have satisfied the requirements of such subsection for such taxable year if—

clause.text: the failure was due to reasonable cause and not due to willful neglect,
no later than 30 days after the discovery of the event causing such failure, the corporation meets the requirements of subsection (a),

in the case of a failure to meet the requirements of subsection (a)(3) for any period, the failure was caused by persons not described therein holding, in the aggregate, less than 1 percent of the stock (by value) of the corporation, and
the corporation pays the additional tax imposed by reason of subparagraph (B).

subparagraph.header: Imposition of additional tax on certain failures
subparagraph.text: In the case of a failure described in subparagraph (A)(iii) for any taxable year, the tax imposed by section 998A(a) on the IRIC shall be equal to the sum of—

clause.text: the tax determined under such section (without regard to this subparagraph) on amounts received by the IRIC for the taxable year other than amounts so received which are attributable to stock held by persons not described in subsection (a)(3) for the period so held, plus
100 percent of the amounts received which are so attributable.

subparagraph.continuation-text: The Secretary shall prescribe rules for the proper allocation of deductions to amounts described in this subparagraph.

subsection.text: In the case of an IRIC, there shall be imposed, in lieu of the tax imposed by section 11, a tax equal to 30 percent of the excess of—

paragraph.text: the amounts received by the IRIC which (before the application of any treaty) would be subject to tax under section 871(a) if received by a nonresident alien individual, over

the deductions properly allocable to such amounts (other than deductions allowed under sections 163, 172, 243, and such other provisions as the Secretary may prescribe in regulations to prevent abuse).
In the case of a treaty IRIC, subsection (a) shall be applied by substituting 15 percent for 30 percent.
For purposes of paragraph (1), the term treaty IRIC means an IRIC—

subparagraph.text: all the outstanding stock of which is held by persons resident in a country that has in effect with the United States an income tax treaty pursuant to which such persons would, by reason of section 894(a), be subject to tax under section 871(a) on dividends at a rate not greater than 15 percent, and
which elects to be a treaty IRIC.

paragraph.continuation-text: Rules similar to the rules of section 998(b) shall apply to an election under subparagraph (B).

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (e), an IRIC shall not be treated as a regulated investment company for purposes of this title.

paragraph.text: No carryforward, and no carryback, arising for a taxable year for which the corporation is not an IRIC may be carried to a taxable year for which such corporation is an IRIC.
No carryforward, and no carryback, shall arise for a taxable year for which a corporation is an IRIC.

subsection.text: Sections 55, 531, and 541 shall not apply to an IRIC.
No credits under this chapter shall be allowed to an IRIC.
In applying section 302(b)(5), an IRIC shall be treated as a publicly offered regulated investment company.

paragraph.text: With respect to the requirement in sections 998(a)(3) and 998A(b)(2)(A), a corporation may rely on the certification of its shareholders, unless or until such time that the corporation has reason to know that the certification is false or is no longer true.

If a corporation has reason to know that the certification made by one of its shareholders is false or is no longer true, the corporation must redeem the stock held by such shareholder as soon as reasonably practicable (and in no case more than 30 days after the corporation obtains such reason to know). Failure to redeem such stock in a timely manner shall result in the corporation failing the requirement of section 998(a)(3) or 998A(b)(2)(A), whichever is applicable.

For purposes of this subsection, a certification with regard to a person which is made by an institution described in section 871(h)(5)(B) in a form satisfactory to the Secretary under section 871(h) shall be deemed to be a certification by such person.

subsection.text: The table of parts for subchapter N of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by redesignating the item relating to part V as relating to part VI and inserting after the item relating to part IV the following new item:
The amendments made by this section shall apply to taxable years beginning after the date of the enactment of this Act.
